item.title: Britain’s riots put spotlight on far-right misinformation
item.dc:creator: Ishaan Tharoor
item.description: Social media posts — including a few by X owner Elon Musk — have played a crucial role in accelerating rage and misinformation.

item.title: U.S., Egypt, Qatar urge Israel, Hamas to restart Gaza cease-fire talks
item.dc:creator: Karen DeYoung
item.description: Israel said it would send a delegation to the resumed negotiations, to be held in Cairo or Doha, Qatar. Hamas gave no immediate response.

item.title: Ukraine, powered by Western arms, stuns Russia in cross-border assault
item.dc:creator: Isabelle Khurshudyan, Alex Horton, John Hudson, Samuel Oakford
item.description: A surprise Ukrainian attack into Russia’s Kursk region appeared to use Western-donated fighting vehicles. The U.S. offered no objections to the operation.

item.title: Israel strikes Gaza schools, saying Hamas uses them to plan attacks
item.dc:creator: Loveday Morris, Hazem Balousha, Hajar Harb
item.description: Israel targeted two schools in Gaza City on Thursday, killing at least 16 people, the civil defense force said.

item.title: Israel repelled Iran’s first direct attack. Is it ready for the next one?
item.dc:creator: Shira Rubin
item.description: There is apprehension in Israel about the strength of its regional anti-Tehran coalition and the ability of its air defense systems to repel a complex assault.

item.title: Catalan leader Puigdemont reemerges in Spain, then vanishes, evading arrest
item.dc:creator: Ellen Francis, Beatriz Ríos
item.description: Carles Puigdemont had been in self-imposed exile since a bid for Catalan independence in 2017. His return is a challenge to Spanish authorities.

item.title: Maduro boasts 2,200 arrests since election; rights groups say 23 dead
item.dc:creator: Samantha Schmidt
item.description: The number of detainees has been too high for defense lawyers to keep up.

item.title: Taylor Swift cancels Vienna shows after two arrested on suspicion of plotting attack
item.dc:creator: Anika Seth, Victoria Bisset, Souad Mekhennet
item.description: Authorities found explosive devices and Islamic State propaganda in the home of one of the suspects, 19. Swift’s concerts were expected to draw more than 150,000 people.

item.title: Banksy’s mysterious trail of animal-themed art delights and confuses London
item.dc:creator: Adela Suliman
item.description: The anonymous street artist Banksy has revealed four animal-themed murals in four days in London, with many speculating there could be more to come this week.

item.title: Japan issues first ‘megaquake’ warning for Nankai Trough after strong temblor
item.dc:creator: Julia Mio Inuma, Niha Masih
item.description: After a 7.1-magnitude quake, Japan’s meteorological agency said there is a higher chance of a major quake in the nearby trough that could trigger powerful tsunamis.

item.title: After a week of U.K. riots, thousands fill the streets to decry racism
item.dc:creator: William Booth, Karla Adam
item.description: For the most part, the counterdemonstrators appeared to outnumber the agitators. And, for one night at least, they helped stop the violence.

item.title: As war looms and flights dwindle, Lebanese grapple with whether to flee
item.dc:creator: Susannah George, Suzan Haidamous
item.description: The exodus from Lebanon began last week after back-to-back assassinations targeted a Hezbollah commander near Beirut and Hamas leader Ismail Haniyeh in Tehran.

item.title: Putin calls cross-border attack in Kursk region a ‘provocation’
item.dc:creator: Francesca Ebel
item.description: The Russian president confirmed that Ukrainian forces had crossed the border into the Kursk region of western Russia.

item.title: Thailand takes another backward step by banning main opposition party
item.dc:creator: Ishaan Tharoor
item.description: On Aug. 7, Thailand’s constitutional court banned Pita Limjaroenrat — the country’s most popular politician — from holding office and dissolved his party.

item.title: Man stole thousands of rare ‘Bluey’ coins worth $393,000, police say
item.dc:creator: Adela Suliman
item.description: The man, who was arrested, stole 63,000 Bluey coins, or “Dollarbucks,” from the back of a truck, Australian police said. Only a tiny proportion have been recovered.

item.title: Ukraine counts on its Olympic athletes to demonstrate ‘the will to win’
item.dc:creator: Claire Parker, Anastacia Galouchka
item.description: High jumper Yaroslava Mahuchikh and fencer Olga Kharlan are among those in Paris trying to not just excel, but to lift up the nation and act as diplomats.

item.title: Who are Hamas’s top leaders? What to know about Yehiya Sinwar.
item.dc:creator: Bryan Pietsch, Cate Brown, Sammy Westfall, Adela Suliman, Niha Masih
item.description: Sinwar, Hamas’s leader in Gaza and the mastermind of the Oct. 7 attack on Israel, will succeed Ismail Haniyeh as the new head of its political bureau.

item.title: The seductive Spanish village where the past feels present
item.dc:creator: Michael Robinson Chávez
item.description: Spanish picnics, Flamenco guitar and Andalusian horses make the past feel present on the dusty road to El Rocío.

item.title: Walz has a long history with China. But he’s not ‘pro-China.’
item.dc:creator: Rebecca Tan, Vic Chiang
item.description: Vice President Harris’s running mate taught in China in 1989, sparking an enduring interest in the country but also leading him to criticize its human rights abuses.
